The need for gapfill methods isnât new, said Aaron Fellis, vice president and general manager of Dielectric ALD products, but the traditional ones no longer meet todayâs needs, especially as 3D NAND is stacked higher. âThey’re so tall and they have a number of different features that get etched through them to enable the integration of different steps,â he said. âUltimately, they need to get filled back up with a dielectric material, most commonly silicon oxide.â Legacy techniques, such as chemical vapor deposition, diffusion/furnace, and spin-on processes that are normally used as gapfill for semiconductor manufacturing are no longer viable for 3D NAND, Fellis said, due to trade-offs between quality, shrinkage, and gapfill voids. âThey tend to shrink and distort the actual structure that the customer is building and designing.â Silicon oxide continues to be a preferred material for filling because itâs stable, withstands a wide range of temperatures, and exhibits good electrical performance. (Image source: Lam Research) But even with good material density that in turn supports good mechanical integrity inside it, said Fellis, standard ALD can still lead to gaps in some devices and thereâs some doubt as to its extendibility.
